plist.p: Welcome to the SABMiller 2013 First Half Results Conference Call. I will now turn the call over to SABMiller. Please go ahead.

Good morning, everyone, and welcome to SABMiller's first half results presentation for our six months ended September 30, 2012. With me today is Jamie Wilson, our CFO, and Alan Clark, our Chief Operating Officer, who will also participate in the Q&A later in the webcast.

As usual, our presentation will contain forward-looking statements which reflect the current best judgment of management including risks and uncertainties. We disclaim any obligation to update these statements outside of our normal reporting and seminar routines.

So, let's get started. This half year, SABMiller's proven approach to delivering organic revenue and profit growth was, again, effective. Strengthened brand portfolios and our development of local beer markets on the ground drove broad-based revenue and profit growth.

Underlying volumes, pricing and mix are all trending positively and contributing to margins offsetting global raw material cost increases and some local market and currency pressures. The breadth of our local portfolios, with pricing, package and style developed to suit each market, is allowing us to create volume growth in the premium, mainstream and more affordable segments and providing us with effective revenue management levers.

Although there have been a slowing of growth in most emerging markets towards the end of the first half, notably in Latin America and China, we believe their economic fundamentals remain promising over the longer term. We're confident that those markets will continue to deliver a disproportionate share of global growth, even as they become still larger in scale. The IMF forecasts that these markets will overtake developed markets in size in 2013.

In this context, our superior position in the emerging markets will continue to pay dividends. This position was created not merely from exposure but is rooted deeply in local marketplaces, up and down the value chain, from farmers through to the distribution, to retailers and consumers and, of course, through constant exposure and contact with local governments.

We've continued to strengthen and update our local flagship brands in the core mainstream and local premium segments around the world. These leading brands retain extremely strong equity with consumers and continue to generate the bulk of our local profit growth. Brand franchises from Tyskie to Castle, from Aguila to Mosi to Snow continue to drive performance and are in strong health.

Local premium and craft beers, as you're aware, are undergoing a renaissance in many markets, as consumers seek out beers whose premium credentials are based on local differentiation and authenticity. We've historically created and led in local premium in emerging markets, and we're now doing more to develop this across the world. And this is being complemented by product innovation across a wide range of styles and prices and countries. From craft and ciders in the U.S. and Europe to recipes with different flavors and raw material bases in Africa, we've accelerated innovation up and down the price data, and this will continue throwing consumers into the category on the basis of both appeal and, in some cases, greater affordability.
With that, I'd like to hand over now to Jamie for the financial review.

Thank you and good day, everyone. We'll start by looking at our earnings per share performance. The Group has delivered strong adjusted earnings per share growth in all of our major currencies. In the first six months, this represents a 14% growth in U.S. dollar terms. This reflects good organic EBITDA growth boosted by the acquisition of Foster's. Revenue and profit growth have been healthy with underlying volumes, pricing and mix all trending positively and contributing to margin development. The interim dividend is $0.24 per share, which represents an increase of 12% over the same period last year.

Despite the moderation in growth in some emerging markets in the latter months of the half, we grew volumes and revenues across most regions. Lager volumes increased 3.9% on an organic basis versus the prior year, led by strong growth in Africa by 6% and Europe up 9% against the weaker comparative and helped in Poland by the Euro 2012 Football Tournament. A 6.1% increase in organic soft drink volumes was driven by Africa and South Africa generating total volume growth of 4.4% on an organic basis.

Organic constant currency Group revenue grew by 7.6%, reflecting a combination of higher volumes, collective price increases and improved brand mix in most regions. Organic constant currency EBITDA grew by 9.4%, mainly due to revenue growth and an improvement in organic margins of 30 basis points.

There's been a positive impact on operating metrics from the acquisition of Foster's, our alliance with Anadolu Efes, and the management combination of our Angolan and Nigerian businesses with Castel, all completed in the second half of last year. At the same time, most of our main operating currencies have weakened against the U.S. dollar, so the performance trends and reported on organic terms vary somewhat.

This chart illustrates these differing trends. Reported growth is reduced by around 6% by currency translation, so we had the exchange – so had the exchange rates remained at last year's level, we'll be reporting Group revenue up 18% and EBITDA up 24%. Taking out the net effect of the M&A activity, most significantly the contribution from Foster's in the half year, we get back to our constant currency organic growth rates of 7.6% for Group revenue and 9.4% for EBITDA. In the second half, we will begin to cycle the inclusion of Foster's from the December 16.

For the rest of my presentation, I'll focus on organic constant currency performance. Group revenue per hectoliter increased 3% on organic constant currency basis, and all regions other than Europe grew compared with the prior period. Latin America benefited from selective price increases and positive brand mix across the region driven by our premium brand growth.

North America firm pricing and favorable brand mix resulted from the Tenth and Blake division growth, mainly driven by Leinenkugel's and Blue Moon as well as downweighting of our economy beer segment.

In Africa, strong performance from our subsidiaries, assisted by price increases and mix benefits from the growth of both Castle Lite and local premium brands in a number of countries, drove the increase. Price and mix benefits in China and India drove the 6% increase in Group revenue per hectoliter in Asia Pacific. South Africa benefited from a moderate price increase taken in lager and below inflationary price increases in the soft drinks portfolio.

In Europe, the decline in unit revenue of 2% was driven by the growth of our economy brands, particularly Ciucas in Romania, targeted price reductions in Poland and the continued consumer shift from the high value, on-premise to the off-premise channel in a number of markets and growth of discounters in that channel.

Raw material input costs for the half-year were up by mid-single digits on a constant currency per hectoliter basis versus the prior year, which was in line with our previous guidance. We've seen higher brewing raw material costs, with both – driven by higher barley prices and rising energy prices. And those energy costs have flown through into some packaging cost as well as distribution cost.

These increases have been partially offset by savings achieved through our global procurement program. As always, cost pressure has varied between regions with the steepest rises in Europe, Africa and South Africa.

Reported EBITA margin benefited from the acquisition of Foster's and was up 100 basis points to 18.2%. On an organic basis, we saw improvement in most regions, an overall increase of 30 basis points despite the rise in input cost.

Organic constant currency EBITA margin in Latin America grew strongly due to slight price increases, volume growth and combined with the variable reduction and other cost efficiencies. Performance in Castel boosted Africa's EBITA margin, with subsidiary margins under pressure from capacity expansion-related costs, input costs and investment in marketing.

Asia's EBITA margins were level with the improved top line performance in China and India, offset by increased marketing and sales cost in China. South Africa beverages' EBITA margin benefited from price increases, operational efficiencies and fixed cost productivity, however, was impacted by the one-off excise charge in our associate, Distell.

North America margin improved due to strong pricing and brand mix and the phasing of information system costs partly offset by higher marketing spend. Europe EBITA margin declined driven by the negative mix, selective price reductions and higher raw material costs, together with an increased level of marketing spend in advance of peak trading.

Total exceptional charges of $127 million have been taken against the profit before tax in the first six months of the year. Our business capability program costs have reduced this year as expected. Program exceptional costs totaled $70 million in the first half of the year, mainly relating to the preparation for enhancements for the deployment of the global IS solution in Poland.

$10 million of exceptional charges relate to non-cash IFRS 2 share-based payment charges relating to employee components of the black economic empowerment program in South Africa. And costs of $47 million were incurred in relation to Foster's integration and restructuring following the Foster's and Pacific Beverages acquisitions. These costs improved the closure of a brewery line at Abbotsford and soft drinks production at Cascade.

Net operating benefits were expected to reach $250 million this year in line with previous guidance. Procurement continues to be the main contributor with an increasing flow of projects in non-production spend areas adding to that in the more established co-players of raw material and packaging. Manufacturing in some regions and sales and distribution benefits also continue.

Our global ERP implementation progress continues. The design and build of the global template has been completed and this is in the process of being thoroughly tested in Poland. Work to transition from projects-led structure into business as usual operations in IS is in hand. We continue to progress with shared services. We have centralized our treasury operations for European countries and are implementing the same in Africa resulting in both financial and operational benefits.

Despite the adverse foreign exchange translation, adjusted EBITDA comprising EBITDA before cash flows from exceptional items, together with dividend received from MillerCoors, increased to 12% on the prior year with underlying growth enhanced by the contribution from Foster's.

In aggregate, the level of operational working capital was unchanged but there was an outflow in the period due to the timing of payments, including the settlement of some costs provided in Australia combined with higher receivables in Europe as the modern trade channel becomes more important.

Capital expenditure, including that on intangible assets for the first half of the year, was $105 million lower than the prior period. We continue to invest to address capacity constraints and to support growth particularly in Africa. The adjusted net finance cost increased by 70% to $391 million following the increase in volumes related to the Foster's transaction.

The Group's effective tax rate of 27.5% was 100 basis points lower than the rate in the first half of last year, primarily as a result of geographic changes in profit mix together with the tax effects of debt taken on with the Foster's acquisition. Free cash flow increased by $205 million versus the prior period; however, the timing of cash flows generated in a one-off inflow in Australia from tax and with a specific timing factor and that will reverse in the next year.

Our net debt position as of 30th of September has decreased over the last six months reflecting partial repayment of the Foster's acquisition facility, and the repayment at maturity of bonds in Colombia and South Africa. As a result, gearing has decreased to 65% and net debt to adjusted EBITDA to 2.6x. Our access to liquidity remains strong with committed headroom available to comply with all covenants on existing borrowings and to fund ongoing capital expenditure.

We remain on track to return to net debt to adjusted EBITDA to its target range of between 2x and 2.5x within the next 18 months in line with our stated financial policy. Our weighted average interest rate on gross debt as at 30th September has decreased to 4.4%, down from 4.9% at the end of March. This is primarily due to the repayment of higher interest rate debt combined with lower floating interest rate, most notably in euros and Australian dollars. The majority of our debt continues to be held in floating rates.

And now the outlook, although we have seen moderation of economic growth in some countries in recent months, the fundamental potential of emerging markets in which we operate remains strong. In that context, we expect our brand, channel, and capacity development initiatives to continue to drive top line growth.

We expect input cost pressures to continue at a similar level to the first half of the year, up mid-single digits on a per hectoliter basis, and we will selectively raise prices where market conditions permit. A positive impact from acquisitions and business combinations seen in the first half of the year will reduce as we cycle the completion dates in the second half, although synergy generation will continue.

As previously advised, capital expenditure for the full year is anticipated to amount to approximately $1.6 billion, with new brewing capacity in South Sudan and Nigeria already coming on stream and elsewhere under construction in Ghana, Tanzania, Peru, Uganda, and Zambia. Finally, our effective tax rate for the half year was set at our current expectations the full year at 27.5% towards the lower end of our advised range of 27% to 29%.

Thanks, Jamie. And now, turning to our commercial review. Just in Latin America, we've intensified our execution in trade in the past year. This and our broader brand and package portfolios have driven further gains in our share of alcohol, which we regard as a key metric in that region. Capturing share of alcohol with initiatives of spanning all price segments. This includes some progress in persuading consumers of informal alcohol to switch to our products in markets such as Colombia and Peru.

Spain and Colombia, earlier this year, we began rolling out key brand presentations of larger 750-ml jumbo bottles designed to create a sharing culture and to improve affordability in the on-premise, while also supporting consumption in the home.

Our profit and margin growth in Latin America remained strong. Lager volume growth of 4% in the half year was complemented by price increases over the last 12 months, and positive brand mix. Revenue per hectoliter grew by 4% on a constant currency basis and helped to drive robust EBITA growth of 14% on the same basis.

Recently, the economic backdrop has become less favorable though with headwinds in some markets, resulting in lower, slower growth. Colombia, in particular, which had demonstrated good GDP growth and low inflation, has cooled somewhat. Strong currency and weak export markets have dampened manufacturing activity and in turn employment and consumption growth.

Despite this, the medium-term outlook for Colombia remains strong. It's forecast by the EIU to remain one of the region's most attractive investment locations over the next five years. The forecast GDP growth of above the rest of Latin America. And our outlook for our other Latin American markets is simply positive.

In Europe, the timing of an economic recovery remains uncertain. The effect of the crisis on beer markets has varied widely within the region. Most Western European markets are declining with growth evident further east. The capital consumption is reaching or even surpassing previous highs. Our own organic volume growth was 9% in the period, with share gains across nearly all of our markets. We've increased support behind our core flagship brands which maintained leading market share positions.

As an example, the picture on this slide includes images which were part of our very successful Tyskie 5th stadium marketing campaign. Tyskie and our overall business in Poland grew market share significantly during the period. But much higher input costs, increased marketing, some selective price reductions and negative mix drove Europe EBITA down 5%, margins falling 200 basis points on an organic constant currency basis. The negative mix results from established structural trends in the region in favor of non-returnable packaging and modern chain and discount channels. Both of these changes are dilutive in the industry margins.

In this environment, our re-based businesses are capitalizing on their brand equities and building new commercial capabilities suited at the time. Our focus is on regaining profit growth, increasingly sophisticated revenue and category management, tools and processes.

We've launched numerous premium price innovations across our markets using consumer insight into demand trends particularly among younger adults. Many of these involved intrinsic differentiation completing suite of testing products such as new flavors of Redd's in Poland and Frisco in Czech Republic and low alcohol Radlers to be launched in Poland and Czech as shown in the picture here, Hungary and Slovakia.

We've also launched specialty premium beers in a number of our markets such as Książęce in Poland, which is shown in the picture. That's available in wheat, dark and red variants and then Fénix [Phoenix] wheat beer in Czech.

The alliance with Efes contributed positively to our EBITA growth, but competitive dynamics in Turkey and the integration in Russia had an adverse effect on their lager volumes which were down 5% for the half year on a pro forma basis. Efes soft drink operations through CCI had a strong half. Volumes up 9% on a pro forma basis and margins also rising.

In North America, MillerCoors' sales to retailers were down 2% on a fairly daily adjusted basis offset by revenue per hectoliter growth of 4% due to firm pricing and strongly positive brand mix. These, combined with continuing cost savings, drove EBITA up 6% in the period. North America EBITA margins up 50 basis points. Advertising and trade activation of MillerCoors Premium Light portfolio is intensifying and will continue to do so for the balance of the year. Coors Light is on its way to eight years of consecutive growth, higher volume and segment share. The brand positioning of the Rocky Mountain cold refreshment continues to resonate well to consumers.

Focus on Miller Lite continues. MillerCoors is increasing support behind It's Miller Time with strong investment in sports and entertainment partnerships, especially – special football packaging, NASCAR activation and new programs for Thanksgiving growing up to today's holiday. Packaging upgrades including the punch-top can and new tap handles are having a positive effect. And the repositioning of Miller64 has also generated improved trend with campaign linked to a New Year's resolution of health, wellness, and being active set to continue its momentum.

Tenth and Blake continues to outperform the growth of the craft segment with volumes up in double digits in the first half of the financial year. Leinenkugel's Summer Shandy has been the major driver of that, delivering 32% growth for the Leinie's franchise in the period, and leading to a year-round rotation of Shandy, starting with Leinie's Lemon Berry Shandy which is doing very well as we speak.

The Blue Moon franchise also continues to drive growth, continuing this autumn, its Pumpkin Ale and three innovations set to launch in 2013, tapping into the wide range of craft beer drinkers from basic exploration to deeper experimentation.

Other craft initiatives, Batch 19 and Henry Weinhard's are expanding off a strong consumer feedback. Third Shift is set to launch in early 2013, with Redd's Apple Ale, shown on the slide, to be rolled out nationally by the end of the first quarter of the year.

And then moving to Africa, despite economic and excise tax headwinds in some markets, our operations on the continent continue to generate robust organic lager volume and EBITA growth of 6% and 19% on an organic constant currency basis. Our trade execution and full portfolio focus enable us to drive volume growth ahead of GDP across most markets. We significantly increased our outlet reach and distribution capitalizing on our expanded brewery footprint.

Our integrated trade service packages create improved drinking environment and cold beer availability shelf created beer category growth. Our product and package innovations are stretching the price ladders attracting new consumers into the category and generating trade-up. The world's first lager made from cassava was launched in Mozambique and has been received enthusiastically. Castle Lite is a resounding success in the markets in which it's been launched, filling the demand for aspirational premium brands into which middle class consumers trade up on special occasions.

For example, in Tanzania, that brand has grown to over 100,000 hectoliters and driven 31% growth in the premium segment over the past two years. Our partner Castel has also continued delivering good volume growth in both beer and soft drinks. The integration of the business in Angola is delivering synergies ahead of expectations and making a material contribution to Africa's EBITA margins.

Our Asia Pacific region has reported some mixed performances. As I'm sure you're already aware, growth at cost consumer categories in China has moderated. CR Snow grew volumes by 4% on an organic basis, just ahead of the industry with share increases led by the Snow brand. Beer prices continued to increase, albeit more slowly in an environment of wage and cost inflation. CR Snow continues to penetrate premium outlets with the portfolio of Snow premium variants, notably Snow Draft, contributing to the 11% organic constant currency revenue growth for the region of the half year. However, price and mix, while partly mitigating cost pressures, were not enough to grow margins. Headwinds include higher sales costs in premium channels and increased competitor intensity, particularly in provinces that are clearly attractive to new entrants.

Our Indian business performed very well, putting volume growth of 23% and strong EBITA growth. Our differentiated state by state strategy continues to succeed. And recent portfolio expansions include Indus Pride, which is shown here on the slide, creating a new segment of lagers with local flavor profiles, extensions to Foster's and Royal Challenge and Miller High Life premium segments in major cities. Our selective investment model should continue to drive both volume and profit here.

In Australia, the adverse trends within the beer and the alcohol industry continue, exacerbated at the present by low consumer confidence. CUB's volume performance was worse than that of the industry. This is before the start of program of management actions to improve marketing and sales. The trends were partly mitigated by improved pricing discipline and a deliberate focus on revenue management. The integration plan is on track. We recently announced the restoration of the flagship Victoria Bitter brand, back to its full flavor and full strength position. This has been extremely well received with some promising early signs.

In South Africa, constant currency revenue grew by double-digits driven mainly by continued volume and share growth of Castle Lite in the premium segment. Our increased premium segment share in South Africa is striking, as shown here on the slide. Aggregate lager volumes grew despite challenging economic conditions, including electricity and fuel price hikes. Focus on market-facing investment and retail execution continue to deliver. Mainstream volume performance was led by Castle Lager, which continues to benefit from the sponsorship of national sports teams.

Our intensified sales efforts and combination of direct and indirect distribution continue to bear fruit in the form of stronger retail relationships and further improved beer market share. The pricing in the soft drink business in South Africa was held back to improve competitiveness in the 2 liter PET format. And this contributed to strong soft drink volume growth of 8% for the half.

Growth has been driven by our efforts to extend our service to retailers particularly in townships. Looking further ahead, we expect this trend to continue strongly. Demographic segment comparisons versus Mexico on the slide here provide an interesting perspective. Both beer and soft drinks businesses continue to extract scale and efficiency benefits which are driving EBITA margins up significantly.

Now, before I conclude, I will spend some time on our four strategic priorities highlighting some specific examples of progress against each. The Foster's and Efes transactions now contribute to our balanced and attractive global spread of businesses. And as you can see from the above charts, we are now more evenly spread around the world. We are, without question, the most diversified company in the peer group. Though we do have the highest exposure to emerging markets, it's our ability to nurture and grow our business ahead of underlying economic growth through excellent execution of relevant and appropriate local brand propositions that makes us proud.

We continue to develop strong and relevant brand portfolios that win in the local market. I want to highlight two examples here. First, the development of MillerCoors' superior craft and import portfolio in the U.S. through a purpose built commercial unit, Tenth and Blake, which ensures that they are given the right focus by MillerCoors and by our distributors.

This is designed to provide consumers and shoppers with a purchase and consumption environment which matches the premium credentials of each specific brand. Tenth and Blake has delivered significant growth ahead of the market and above the craft import segment broadly. We expect MillerCoors to continue to develop our portfolio in the above premium space and thus drive revenue growth.

Second example shows the development of our portfolio in Poland, not only in terms of brands but also in terms of how we are winning in the market through superior execution which is an important part of the strategic priority.

As you are aware, we moved some of our prices downward in Poland at the beginning of the financial year. A key objective was to ensure price compliance at retail across the large traditional trade universe in Poland. This was successfully achieved and was an important contributor to our volume performance in the country.

At the same time, we've been improving premium and super premium execution through focusing on the right brand proposition, the right outlets. We've also extended our premium portfolio through innovation including new liquids, packaging, and price points. Constantly strive to raise the profitability of local businesses sustainably. One example is Colombia where our premium and super premium brands showed growth of 6% assisted by the enlarged Club Colombia franchise shown here, which is beneficial to brand mix.

And second, a very relevant example of raising profitability in our local businesses is South Africa, where we've grown margin significantly in both beer and soft drinks over the past three years. This was despite the economic headwinds as a direct result of management actions to drive top line revenue and cost savings. Profitability has benefited from the price mix effect of continued volume growth on the premium priced Castle Lite, while soft drink profitability has been driven by a restructuring and significant reduction in distribution costs.

Apart from the business capability program and other projects, we're also leveraging our global skill. The new global talent model was approved by our executive committee in September 2010 and is being implemented across our businesses. Implementation in Australia currently underway. The second year of implementation, the impact has been positive, we are making better and more effective deployment decisions for the long term. We're less reactive and much more deliberate about who we move where and are able to take calculated risks with strong high potential talent.

This financial year, 32 moves of executive talent have been made between and across regions. Our talent pool is truly global, the executives filling our top 200 positions spanning over 40 nationalities of origin, and from all continents, except, of course, Antarctica, where we don't yet have a presence.

And so to conclude, a reminder of our key points today. Our strong revenue growth continues this half year driving underlying EBITA growth of some 9%. Our proven approach to brand and beer market development continues to deliver, pricing mix and cost efficiencies further contributing to the result.

We believe that emerging market fundamentals remained strong despite some current moderation in growth this year. Our model of leading local flagship brands, innovation and expanding premium assortment is working as we've shown across many markets. And as Jamie described, we continue to invest in our future growth in the form of capacity, systems and capability.
With that, operator, we'll be happy to take your questions either over the phone line or through our Internet webcast.
Thank you, sir. Thank you. Our first question comes from Trevor Stirling of Sanford Bernstein. Please go ahead with your question.

Good morning, Graham and Jamie and Alan. Three questions please. The first one concerning Europe. You've taken the margin adjustment in Europe and that's showing up in the first half numbers. Is it right way you think about this that that adjustment will continue to the second half and then we should be into a somewhat more stable margin environment?

Second question relates to Africa. I think Graham you talked about the subsidiaries – subsidiary margins being under pressure but you still have 90 basis points of organic margin expansion in the half. Does that imply that the expansion came more from the Castel business and less from your fully-owned business?

And the third question relating to Australia, you talked about pressures on operating leverage being mitigated by revenue management. Is it fair to say that's partially mitigated and at the moment with the 8% volume for all the operating leverage, the pressure on operating leverage is actually greater than the upside from the revenue management at the moment?

Hi, Trevor. I would ask Alan to pick up some of these questions as well. First of all, I'll just pick up the Africa one quickly. Yes, your assumption is correct. The improvement in Africa margins comes from the Castel associate but, of course, their own margins are substantially helped by the Angola transaction to which, of course, we contributed through the combination of the businesses there. So, there's an uplift from that, yes.

For the rest of the Africa subsidiaries, yes, you will know that we've had currency pressure in a number of our markets and that's affected the input costs quite strongly. So there's a slight downward beating in the subsidiary margin, not much but a little bit. Yes. But let's ask.

But perhaps a bit building on that, Graham, I mean, I think we anticipated that at the full year when we said that our margins in the first half will continue to be under pressure as we brought capacity on.

I think also just on the subsidiary point, I mean clearly, the mix of our countries is important in terms of the beat as a whole because to some extent, Angola within our hands, was a lower margin business. And therefore, by combining it with Castel, our subsidiary margin overall actually got a uplift as well as the benefit of the synergies from Angola's prices.
Exactly, although that doesn't show on the organic number, yes. But it's a curiousity what you mean by organic growth in the arithmetic here. Did you understand that point?
Yes, yes, absolutely, Graham. Yes.
All right. Alan, got anything else?

Okay. First of all, I can then pick up on Europe and Australia. Yes, I think the big impact on margins in Europe this year was the price reset as well as the launch of some more competitive packs in a number of markets but more specifically in Romania where we've driven that quite strongly. So we've seen the result of that being the volume uplift, and together with that share regain in those markets, which has been very important for us, but then, obviously, had the impact on margins and overall profits.

I mean going forward we think the European environment's going to remain challenging. So those economies are not in great shape at the moment and we think it's going to take a while to build out of that. I mean, very difficult, of course, to forecast exactly when that will happen.

The other factor, of course, is that the markets are consolidated, so we'll remain highly competitive, I mean, throughout and that certainly is not going to change. In terms of whether this is the bottom, if you like, on the margins, I think the price reset, the share regain and the more competitive stance we've taken in channels was important and I think that we have moved a long way down that track. So, I think, going forward, in terms of our business expectations for Europe, we'd want to see a steady rebuild beginning to come but within, as I've said, a challenging economic environment.

On Australia, the point there about the improved revenue, which we reported 70% in revenue per hectoliter growth, and your question, I think, about how that's played versus the volume decline in Australia, and the reality is that the profitability in Australia on the business now in our hands is actually doing well. So operating profit and financial performance of the business is good, and it's driven largely through that revenue growth plus the synergies that are beginning to come through. I mean, you'll recall the synergy number in your three full year is around $150 million, but, of course, we started getting some of that benefit from the outset. So our synergies and revenue has led to improved profitability in the business and has offset the impact of the volume decline.
Thank you very much indeed.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Anthony Bucalo from Santander. Please go ahead with your question.
Good morning, everyone.

Just a quick question on innovation. It seems to be a theme throughout the release and the discussion today. What kind of impact do you think innovation had on your numbers this half year, specifically on volume, revenue, profit? Is that a sustainable level of innovation? Do you need more, especially in regard to how you're spending on extensions for flagship brands and some of your emerging markets?

Yes. If I could pick that – Tony, if I could pick that up again – the point as I was going forward within the beer category that we are likely – we are seeing and are likely to see ongoing and, in fact, I think an increased momentum of innovation and that's across the globe. I don't think there are any markets in which that will not happen. That's partly a result of the competitiveness between the major brewers around the world. It's partly a consequence of the way consumers are shifting their behavior and their repertoires. And of course, it's an ongoing effort to just present the category as more interesting versus other alcohol types. So innovation is very much a part of the story.

Going forward over the medium to longer term, I mean, I would say that I would look at – we're looking towards the 5% to 10% of revenues coming from innovation. In the shorter term in some of our markets, Europe, perhaps being the most obvious example of that, the revenue contribution has been much higher. So we reported 9% volume growth for Europe in the six months and of that 9%, 60% of it was driven by innovation in brand and pack.

If we exclude pack, which is less obviously, I suppose, innovation and we focus on product and new products go-to-market then that number would be around 35% to 40%, so a substantial portion of that growth driven by innovation. The majority of them occurring in the premium end so a very important part of the business. But in the U.S., Australia, Europe, et cetera, Africa we will see innovation growing moving forward.
Do you see it as a higher expense essentially going forward?

Well, yes. Innovation will cost money in terms of the greater marketing funds and the need to execute across a broader portfolio. But the point is that most of that will be – we'll be focusing that on the premium end. So, I mean, at the gross margin level, in fact we'd want to be positive from a mix impact of innovation. That would be the objective is to have a positive mix effect.
Great. Thanks so much.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Simon Hales from Barclays. Please go ahead with your question.

Hi, thank you, morning, everyone. A couple of questions, please. Just on the business capability delivery, I want to focus – just sort of clarify what you've done there. You've delivered $115 million in the first half. Is that the incremental delivery on the $159 million you delivered in the full year to March 2012, i.e. the cumulative amount now is rolling forward at about $274 million? Or is the $115 million the uplift on last year's first half of $60 million, i.e. a $55 million incremental benefit in the first half this year? I just want to, again, make sure I understand you correctly.

And then secondly, sticking with the cost saving theme and going back to Trevor's question around Africa, how should we think about the Castel delivery as we look forward? Are most of the cost benefits in Angola and Nigeria already being realized or is there more cost saving benefit to come through in the margin in the second half?

And then perhaps finally, Jamie, you talked about input cost guidance for the second half continuing to run at mid-single digits. Can you give us the flavor towards as to how you're perhaps thinking about things to the whole of coming to 2013 at this stage?

Okay, if I can pick up the BCP one, first of all, I mean the number we're talking about here is the cumulative benefit from the project to date. This is not the incremental benefit in the current half. So your latter interpretation in terms of the uplift between the 60-odd last year to the $250 million in this year is the incremental benefit delivered this year relative to last year.
